Issues.Body:
- Should we throw ANE in constructor?
- Or should we check for null in the props!

Issues.Body:
Best reviewed commit-by-commit

Fixes #101

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Add CommonDialog tests, cleanup CommonDialog, and Fix Debug assert in Control.GetSafeHandle" (#880)

Issues.Title: Setting new DataGridColumnStyle().NullText to null unnecessarily invalidates
Issues.Body:
Also calls `OnNullTextChanged` even if nothing

E.g.
```cs
var style = new DataGridBoolColumn();
style.NullText = null;

style.NullText = null; // Invalidates again...
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Setting new DataGridColumnStyle().NullText to null unnecessarily invalidates" (#894)

Issues.Title: Some editors missing
Issues.Body: I can't see System.Drawing.Design.FontNameEditor and System.ComponentModel.Design.MultilineStringEditor.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Some editors missing" (#892)

Issues.Title: Modernizing Winforms images in core (Redo #678)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Modernizing Winforms images in core (Redo #678)" (#886)

Issues.Title: WinForms should test for binary serialization
Issues.Body:
Once you decide which types need to remain serializable #889 you need to test the remaining types for binary serialization.

These types should be tested to ensure they are serializable today, remain serializable in the future, and that they can round-trip to desktop.

Tests will likely involve consuming in binary payloads in test data and consuming this in tests.  You'll also likely want to annotate members that are forzen for serialization purposes.  @ViktorHofer did a lot of this work for CoreFx and may be able to provide some pointers.

This work should be semi-parallelizable with #889 since you know you have some types already that need to stay Serializable (EG: ImageList).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "WinForms should test for binary serialization" (#890)

Issues.Title: System.Windows.Forms should reduce the number of types that use SerializableAttribute
Issues.Body:
Not all types that were Serializable in desktop need to be serializable in .NETCore.  Maintaining SerializableAttribute on types means those types need to be tested for Version to Version serialization and potentially framework-to-framework serialization.  This makes it harder to evolve those types and can be costly to maintain.

We've started looking at types that require Serializable for resource scenarios.  Those must be in.

There are likley some types that the designer needs to be serializable, but those may or may not require binary serialization.  As much as you can you should try to avoid depending on binary serialization for internal only scenarios since it increases the maintainence cost of the public types.

Of the remaining types you need to audit their serialization scenarios and look at usage data.  Previously @ViktorHofer worked on this.  I believe they got some help from @marklio to analyze usage by looking at types marked as serializable and the sorts of fields they might contain.  You might be able to convince them to rerun this analysis and include WinForms assemblies.

Once you decide which ones to remove you can just remove the attribute and test.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Windows.Forms should reduce the number of types that use SerializableAttribute" (#889)

Issues.Title: System.Design name space is missing resources in core.
Issues.Body: Source of System.Design.dll is ported but not all resources are ported.  Also, we may need to port only .ico formats if they were not already and update System.Design source code to use .ico formats from winforms assembly wherever it was earlier referencing .bmp formats
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "System.Design name space is missing resources in core." (#888)

Issues.Title: An error pops up when using the property DefaultCellStyle of DataGridView in the .NET Core 3.0 winforms application
Issues.Body:
**OS:** RS5 X64
**VS:** Visual Studio 2019 Version 16.1.0 Preview 3.0 [28824.157.d16.0]
**.NET SDK:** .NET Core 3.0.100-preview5-011555 from release branch
**Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?:** No
**More Info:** 
1. The repro video: \\\mlangfs1\public\Winforms\v-jiaol\bug\DataGridVew\Call with DataGridViewDefaultCellStyleIssueRepro.mp4

**Steps to Reproduce:** 
1. Create a Winforms .Net Core application by command: dotnet new winforms o xxx.
2. Write code to Form1.cs.
   DataGridView dgv = new DataGridView();;
           DataGridViewCellStyle style = new DataGridViewCellStyle();
           style.BackColor = Color.Red;
           dgv.RowTemplate.DefaultCellStyle = style;
3. Insert an breakpoint in this code: dgv.RowTemplate.DefaultCellStyle = style; and debug the application.

**Actual:** 
When debugging to dgv.RowTemplate.DefaultCellStyle= style;, the exception pops up.
![bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49627022/56728615-cda58980-6785-11e9-8851-03258fe4ff7d.png)




**Call Stack:** 
 System.NullReferenceException
  HResult=0x80004003
  Message=Object reference not set to an instance of an object.
  Source=System.Windows.Forms
  StackTrace:
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewBand.set_DefaultCellStyle(DataGridViewCellStyle value)
   at System.Windows.Forms.DataGridViewRow.set_DefaultCellStyle(DataGridViewCellStyle value)
   at WindowsFormsApp2.Form1..ctor() in C:\Users\v-jiaol\source\repos\WindowsFormsApp2\WindowsFormsApp2\Form1.cs:line 22
   at WindowsFormsApp2.Program.Main() in C:\Users\v-jiaol\source\repos\WindowsFormsApp2\WindowsFormsApp2\Program.cs:line 19


**Expected:** 
No exception pops up, application runs successfully.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "An error pops up when using the property DefaultCellStyle of DataGridView in the .NET Core 3.0 winforms application" (#879)
